Description: Ampulla; clay; flat, circular sides. On each side, within a border of radiating grooves, is an incuse impression of a bird, perhaps a swan, but probably an eagle, standing to left, with wings raised. Both sides come from moulds produced from the same archetype.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Acquired in Alexandria. Late Roman, about AD 480-650. Comparanda: Close: Heide and Thiel 2004: 147, no. iii.3.30, dated sixth to seventh century AD; Kaufmann 1908: 194, fig. 141:14, from Abu Mena; ibid.: 115, fig. 76:1, a pilgrim token with the same bird and border; Kaufmann 1910: 160, fig. 97, from Abu Mena. Bibliog: Murray 1907: pl. ii:5.
Bibliographic references: Dalton 1901 / Catalogue of Early Christian Antiquities and Objects from the Christian East in the Department of British and Medieval Antiquities and Ethnography of the British Museum (901)
Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3461)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
